column16: International Federation of Red Cross and Red Crescent Societies
column20: UCLBP - Construction Unit for Habitat and Public Buildings
column127: The beneficiaries could choose between having a shelter with a floor level raised above the ground level, or having the shelter constructed on the original floor level of the previous house.
column143: tie (between ridge beam and king post/ truss)
column159: To control ventilation and privacy, PVC louvers were used for the windows.
column183: The beneficiary installed a lamp on the electricity grid for lighting, electricity is only provided a few hours a day.
column191: The partition in the shelter was added by the beneficiary.

column20: UCLBP - Construction Unit for Habitat and Public Buildings
column71: Strip footing made with rock masonry is used for the foundations, with additional footing made of reinforced concrete, where columns appear in the walls.
column81: vertical wall reinforcement in corners
column118: beam and blocks/ beam fill floor (concrete joists and infill blocks)
column159: 2 doors per floor are provided, as well as 4 windows on the ground floor and 5 windows on the first floor, all are made of welded metal profiles, painted with anti-corrosion paint.
column191: Extension to the building could be made in the future, ensuring that there is a gap between the 2 structures to preserve the earthquake resistance of both buildings.

column20: UCLBP - Construction Unit for Habitat and Public Buildings
column71: For shelters installed on an existing slab, expansion anchors were used to attach the base plate to the existing concrete slab at 0,6m intervals. In other cases the 0,09mx0,09m ACQ treated wooden posts with metal plate bolted at the bottom, were buried minimum 0,6m under ground level.
column73: Technical details of the ground slab/foundations that existed before shelter construction are unknown at the moment of this survey.
column90: studs located every 60 cm (2 ft) or less
column127: Technical details/thickness of the ground slab/foundations that existed before shelter construction are unknown at the moment of this survey.
column145: To ensure roof stability, metal diagonal roof bracing is nailed on top of the trusses, below the purlins.
column159: The plywood used for cladding of the facades was used horizontally, creating a horizontal joint 1,2 m above ground level in all elevations, this creates water infiltration as the edges of the plywood start desintegrating.
column183: Ventilation openings were provided in the gable walls at the height of the trusses. The openings were closed by the beneficiaries with leftovers of plywood, or other recycled materials, to prevent insects, rodents from entering and to prevent rainwater infiltration. Drinking water is bought in a kiosque, household water is bought from a truck passing and selling for 0,11 USD per bucket.
column191: Many of the beneficiaries in the urban area closed their veranda with recycled materials (using it as kitchen, storage, ?? in order to have more private/secure space.

column20: UCLBP - Construction Unit for Habitat and Public Buildings
column73: Wooden gusset plates are used to screw the bracing to the studs and the top and bottom wall plates.
column159: The beneficiaries added plastic mesh between the walls and roof overhang to prevent insects from entering the shelter.
column165: no facilities or bush or field

column20: UCLBP - Construction Unit for Habitat and Public Buildings
column71: The wooden superstructure starts 0,59m above ground level. This is to mitigate the risk of termites attacking the wood, the wood is protected from humidity as the humidity absorbed by the base wall evaporates before it can reach the wood.
column73: The timber wall structure with cross bracing, is filled in with masonry of crushed debris.
column143: tie (between ridge beam and king post/ truss)
column159: Mirco concrete tiles are used for the roof covering. The tiles are made with sand obtained from crushed debris. Entrepreneurs du Monde obtained the sand from UNOPS that had a cash for work program for debris removal in the same neighbourhoods. The debris were brought to a site where it was crushed to different diameters, for use in new constructions. In the same way EdM obtained the stones necessary for the masonry to fill in the facades of the wooden structure.
column191: The owner is renting out the house. The construction in this highly dense neighbourhood has a single storey, but is calculated to have a vertical extension, the owner is planning to build a second storey in the future.

column20: UCLBP - Construction Unit for Habitat and Public Buildings
column71: Nails, bolts or spikes should be used at the end of the wood post to ensure that it is adequately encasted in the concrete pad. To minimize the impact of overturning forces during strong winds, the concrete footings could be enlarged up to 0,45m diameter and 0,45 deep.
column73: Attention needs to be paid to a consequent installation of hurricane straps as construction workers who are not used to apply the straps might not be aware of their importance.
column127: Most of the beneficiaries removed the plywood floor at the time of the survey and filled the space under the shelter with backfill, surrounded by hollow concrete block masonry. The plywood was deteriorating quite fast because of humidity, especially on flat sites, where the soils dries slowly after rainfall. The beneficiaries preferred a concrete floor for maintenance.

column20: UCLBP - Construction Unit for Habitat and Public Buildings
column71: Next to the housing component, the program includes the construction of a school, a soccer field, a basketball field and a well, a community health component, educational activities component, an income generation component: construction and activation of a bakery, a pasta factory and a nutritional center.

column2: Canadian Red Cross, TS Type B
column20: UCLBP - Construction Unit for Habitat and Public Buildings
column71: For the foundations, 8 Platipus S6 anchors were used to anchor the wooden columns in the soil. The anchor system had to resist to a minimum service load of 1600 lbs (7,12kN).
column73: The framed walls structure was imported as preassembled components.
column127: The floor exists of compacted earth (recycled from the foundations) the upper 10 cm consist of sifted soil/sand. As temporary finishing, a tarpaulin was put on the compacted earth and fixed on the bottom wall plate with large head nails.
column183: CRC established a partnership with the Netherlands Red Cross in order to provide a pit latrine for each constructed shelter. The latrines were constructed on the site of each beneficiary, and communal water tabs were installed to improve acces to clean water for the beneficiaries and their communities. There is no bathroom in plot of the surveyed shelter.

column2: German and Austrian Red Cross, TS
column20: UCLBP - Construction Unit for Habitat and Public Buildings
column71: At the bottom of every wooden post 8 to 12 nails (5") are placed in order to improve the connection between the wood and the concrete of the foundation.
column73: As untreated wood was used for the structure, the base of the posts are attacked by termites just above ground level. During the upgrade of the T-shelters concrete footings were placed at the base of (some of) the timber posts to protect them for further deterioration.
column127: The earth floor in and around the shelter makes it easy for termites to attack the timber structure. The beneficiary added a cement floor inside the shelter.
column145: The single pitch roof shape is not found in the local construction. Some of the beneficiaries (from the same family) reconstructed a new shelter with the materials of 2 transitional shelters, transformed it in a building with a gable roof.
column159: The plywood used as cladding material for the facade is only removed 10cm from the ground level, resulting in fast deterioration of the lower part due to humidity. Several beneficiaries removed a part of the plywood and replaced it by 4 layers of hollow concrete block masonry.
column191: A simple veranda was added to the shelter with local wood and tarpaulins.

column2: German and Austrian Red Cross, PS
column20: UCLBP - Construction Unit for Habitat and Public Buildings
column71: USP foundation straps were used to connect the 4 corner posts to the concrete pads.
column73: High pressure treated pine wood (grade 2) was used for the structure, in order to prevent the shelter being attacked by termites.
column145: Additional cross bracing in the horizontal plane is installed as a stability measure.
column191: The beneficiaries added a bathroom with a flush toilet and shower (bucket) and they partially closed the veranda.

column20: UCLBP - Construction Unit for Habitat and Public Buildings
column71: The soil type for the shelter should be firm in order to use this foundation design.
column127: The raised floor prevents the shelter from flood damage.
column159: The shelters were implemented in 2 phases: the steel structure covered with tarpaulin as a temporary phase, and the steel structure with cement cladding (strengthened by additional wooden framing) as a durable solution. The technical information in this database focusses on the durable solution. Some shelters were covered with standard CGI sheets (nailed), others were covered with insulated roof panels (fixed with screws). The second solution reduced the temperature inside, but were found more difficult to replace/repair by the beneficiaries.
column183: The shelter program intervened in 14 communities, in all of these IFRC or Spanich Red Cross provided latrines to the shelter beneficiaries, and in 8 of the communities IFRC installed water pumps.

column2: Canadian Red Cross, TS Type A
column20: UCLBP - Construction Unit for Habitat and Public Buildings
column71: The wooden columns of the superstructure continue 1,2 m under the ground level, the lower parts are connected with each other by longitudinal beams at 0,9m under the ground level.
column73: The framed walls structure was imported as preassembled components.
column127: The floor exists of compacted earth (recycled from the foundations) the upper 10 cm consist of sifted soil/sand. As temporary finishing, a tarpaulin was put on the compacted earth and fixed on the bottom wall plate with large head nails.
column183: CRC established a partnership with the Netherlands Red Cross in order to provide a pit latrine for each constructed shelter. The latrines were constructed on the site of each beneficiary, and communal water tabs were installed to improve acces to clean water for the beneficiaries and their communities. There is no bathroom in plot of the surveyed shelter.

column20: UCLBP - Construction Unit for Habitat and Public Buildings
column73: In order to attach the roof structure to the walls, hurricane ties were poured in the ring beam (USP FA3 / USP RT7 / USP RT5)
column81: vertical wall
column183: Ventilation louvres were integrated above the door openings, but most of the beneficiaries closed these due to water infiltration.
column191: The beneficiary constructed a hollow concrete block wall to separate the living room from the bedroom.

column2: Swiss / Belgian Red Cross, improved TS
column7: La Source, Palmiste a Vin, Leogane
column20: UCLBP - Construction Unit for Habitat and Public Buildings
column71: 4 expansion bolts are used to attach the foundation to the superstructure. The distance between the isolated footings differs: 2,2m / 3m / 3,6m
column73: The primary structure of the houses are made of cold formed galvanized steel profiles that are bolted together. The kits are prefabricated and imported, they are assembled on site.
column127: Timber joists were added to the metal frame of the suspended floor in order to attach the plywood to the structure. The beneficiaries of the evaluated house closed the space under the elevated floor of the house and the veranda and finished the floor with a cement layer, as they didn't like the fact that animals were looking for shelter under the house.
column145: As roof stability measyre cable bracing is used, as well as knee braces.

column20: UCLBP - Construction Unit for Habitat and Public Buildings
column71: Nails, bolts or spikes should be used at the end of the wood post to ensure that it is adequately encasted in the concrete pad. To minimize the impact of overturning forces during strong winds, the concrete footings could be enlarged up to 0,45m diameter and 0,45 deep.
column73: Attention needs to be paid to theinstallation of hurricane straps as construction workers who are not used to apply the straps might not be aware of their importance.
column127: Most of the beneficiaries removed the plywood floor at the time of the survey and filled the space under the shelter with backfill, surrounded by a perimeter walls of hollow concrete block masonry. The plywood was deteriorating quite fast because of humidity, and beneficiaries using water for maintenance of the floor.
column191: The beneficiaries improved the veranda floor by adding ceramic tiles and installed a small shop under the covered area.

column20: UCLBP - Construction Unit for Habitat and Public Buildings
column71: Nails, bolts or spikes should be used at the end of the wood post to ensure that it is adequately encasted in the concrete pad.
column73: The walls are closed using the 'clissage' technique, a system which is traditionally used in rural areas.
column159: The beneficiaries put plastic sheeting / CGI sheets inside agains the 'clissage' walls, to reduce rainwater and insects from entering as the openings between the lats are quite large. The beneficiaries that were visited didn't have the financial means to improve the shelter by adding a cement plaster on the clissage. They could add a mud plaster without spending any money. In 'upgradable' shelters it is very important to communicate with the beneficiaries about the options they have to improve their shelter.

column159: The beneficiaries added plastic mesh between the walls and roof overhang to prevent insects from entering the shelter.

column145: 2 construction systems are used for the roof: reinforced concrete slabs, and a timber structure built with rafters and purlins, attached to the ringbeam using hurricane straps.

column16: HAVEN, American Red Cross, Australian Red Cross
column20: UCLBP - Construction Unit for Habitat and Public Buildings
column71: Threaded steel rods are fixed under the bond beam and are attached to the wall, so that it can resist the shear force generated by an earthquake.
column81: bond beam/ring beam at plinth level
column143: tie (between ridge beam and king post/ truss)
column159: The cement plaster is cracking or getting detached at certain spots on the walls, requiring reparation. The corrugated bitumen roofing sheets are leaking.
column183: The houses are located in a low lying area, due to the limited elevation of the concrete floor, and absence of a drainage system, the shelters are regularly flooded.

column2: Adobe block house with tiled roof

column71: The natural soils are extremely hard. As a result the poles of the structure are not buried deep enough (only 10-15cm instead of 30cm) to guarantee necessary anchoring to resist the strong winds.
column73: Although the wood for the shelters is procured from controlled eucalyptus plantations, the government of Burkina Faso has voiced concerns about environmental impact and would like to see the use of wood for the shelters reduced. Uncontrolled logging by Refugees to upgrade their shelters is also unwanted. NRC commissioned an environmental impact study and continues using the eucalyptus wood from local cooperative plantations with controlled processes.
